arch:property.oc:show_val: Subflooring, interior face of Wall Locus 7.

Phase VI: Late Nabataean pre-CE 106 minor collapses and repairs. At this time the northwest subterranean channel is damaged and clogged with CE 1st c. pottery. Repairs are made to the Hexagonal Pavement as well as to the East Exedra walls. Bath Complex built.

This locus is a facing constructed of terracotta tiles that is bonded to the interior (east) face of the West Wall (Locus 7) below the level of the Suspended Floor (Locus 13). The individual tiles are laid horizontally and set with layers of a gray mortar that contains a large quantity of cinders. Since the terracotta tiles were intact in the excavated area, the actual thickness of the facing could not be determined; however, the tiles appear to be the same as the others found in Tr. 126, so the thickness can be approximated at between 0.20Â–0.30 centimeters. Complete removal of the soil fill (Locus 26) to explore this wall facing risked destabilizing the overhanging extant section of the Suspended Floor, so the locus was not completely investigated.
Terracotta Tile Facing Wall, East face of Wall Locus 7 substructure
